gmd:individualName.gco:CharacterString: REQUIRED: The person responsible for the metadata information.

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: REQUIRED: The organization responsible for the metadata information.

gmd:voice.gco:CharacterString: REQUIRED: The telephone number by which individuals can speak to the organization or individual.

gmd:city.gco:CharacterString: REQUIRED: The city of the address.

gmd:administrativeArea.gco:CharacterString: REQUIRED: The state or province of the address.

gmd:postalCode.gco:CharacterString: REQUIRED: The ZIP or other postal code of the address.

gmd:metadataStandardName.gco:CharacterString: ISO 19139 Geographic Information - Metadata - Implementation Specification

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: United States Geological Survey (USGS) Great Lakes Science Center (GLSC)

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
Habitat suitability was estimated for invasive Phragmites in the coastal Great Lakes region (shoreline to 10 km inland). These estimates were based on current distribution patterns and environmental conditions. Phragmites presence or absence was defined based on a distribution map produced by cooperative research between the GLSC and Michigan Technical Research Institute. Environmental variables were processed in a Geographic Information System (GIS) and came from existing publicly available sources. Variables include descriptors of soils, nutrients, topography, ecoregion, anthropogenic disturbance, and climate. Environmental conditions and Phragmites presence/absence were sampled in a GIS at points established at systematic 100-m intervals across the study area.
Habitat suitability was estimated for Phragmites at each systematic sample location. A correlative ecological niche model (boosted regression trees) was used to produce a continuous probabilistic index that ranged between zero and one. This index was rescaled in to six categories of relative habitat suitability by specifying a threshold for suitable/unsuitable conditions where the proportion of presence locations classified as suitable equated to the proportion of absence locations classified as unsuitable. After applying this threshold, the data ranges classified as suitable/unsuitable were split at equal increments to result in six categories of relative suitability.

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: The habitat suitability map is intended to be used in conjunction with the accompanying Phragmites distribution map and corridor networks to provide resource managers and restoration practitioners with a robust means of assessing vulnerability to future invasion by Phragmites. These products may help to identify key areas for monitoring in support of early detection and rapid response, to prioritize control efforts across multiple areas, and/or to develop strategic restoration programs.

gmd:credit.gco:CharacterString: Habitat suitability index was greated by the USGS GLSC and made possible by funding Great Lakes Restoration Initiative (GLRI) administered from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service.

gmd:keyword.gco:CharacterString: Great Lakes coastal wetlands, Great Lakes Restoration Initiative (GLRI), forecasting invasive Phragmites corridors, species distribution modeling, boosted regression trees, vulnerability assessment

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: REQUIRED: Reference to a formally registered thesaurus or a similar authoritative source of theme keywords.

gmd:environmentDescription.gco:CharacterString: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 3; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.1.1850

gmd:supplementalInformation.gco:CharacterString: The temporal validity of this habitat suitability map is defined by the temporal constraints of its inputs. Its dependent/response variable (Phragmites presence/absence) was defined by mapping based off of imagery gathered between 2007 and 2010, and on ground truthing conducted in 2010 and 2011. The fifteen independent variables come from several sources, and the temporal issues for each of these sources varies.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Phragmites habitat suitability across the U.S. Great Lakes coastal zone

gmd:measureDescription.gco:CharacterString: Maps were developed for the U.S. portion of the Great Lakes coastal zone.

gmd:nameOfMeasure.gco:CharacterString: Area Under Curve of Receiver Operator Characteristic (AUC)

gmd:measureDescription.gco:CharacterString: AUC: reflects the fraction of time that a randomly selected presence point would have a higher score than a randomly selected absence point, % dev: the percent reduction in deviance when comparing a null model to the final model

gmd:evaluationMethodDescription.gco:CharacterString: half the sample was withheld for testing, both metrics reflect measures of performance tested on data independent from samples used to train and calibrate the model

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString:
Samples of environmental variable grids and current Phragmites distribution were produced using ArcGIS (v 10.0) Geostatistical Analyst's 'extract values to table' tool within a Python (v 2.6.5) script. These samples were merged, processed and analyzed within R statistical software (v 2.13.0). A boosted regression tree model was developed and tested within R as implemented through the Dismo, GBM, and SDMTools packages. An optimized threshold was established to prepare for reclassifying model outputs in to six categories of relative habitat suitability.
Environmental variables came from several sources, and initially were composed of both vector and raster data types. Regardless of their source, data were converted to 30 m resolution ESRI grids in the Albers equal area coordinate system (NAD 1983) in order to establish a common reference system prior to sampling at systematic point locations. The NHDPlus (v1) Catchment grid was used as a snap raster in order to align cells to the sample position and precision.
Environmental variables included climate, topography, soils, nutrients, road density, population density, land-cover change, Ecoregion, and proximity to agriculture and urban development. These variables were selected based on data availability and our understanding of invasive Phragmites ecology. A description of the variables is below.
Climate was described by bio9, bio11, and bio19 of the Bioclim/Worldclim very high resolution 30 arc second (~1km) data set (http://www.worldclim.org/current). Bio9 represented the mean temperature during the driest quarter.Bio11 represented the mean temperature during the coldest quarter, and bio19 represented mean precipitation of the coldest quarter. The variables are based on ~50 years of climate data from 1950-2000. These data were gathered at weather stations and summarized by monthly averages. Data from the weather stations were interpolated to create a spatially continuous gridded data set (see also Hijmans et al. 2005, available from link above). The three variables were selected from the larger set of nineteen based on the results of linear correlations with Phragmites presence.
Topography was described by rough_sd_r50 from the one-arc-second (~30 m) USGS National Elevation Dataset (NED) (http://seamless.usgs.gov/ned1.php). The NED was clipped and resampled within the reference system described above. Topographic roughness was calculated with the ESRI's Focal Statistics function using the standard deviation of all cells within a 50-cell radius.
Soils were described by glhydgrp3, gldrainagecl3, and glps1rclss. These variables were derived from the USDA SSURGO soils data (http://www.soils.usda.gov/survey/geography/ssurgo/) using a Python script authored by Howard Reeves and Lori Fuller of the USGS Michigan Water Science Center (http://mi.water.usgs.gov/). These data came from the dominant component of each SSURGO map unit. A categorical variable, glhydgrp3 described the hydrologic group of soils based on seven categories. Three of these categories describe hydrologic conditions that are dependent on the drainage management of the soils. The variables gldrainagecl3 and glps1rclss described the drainage and particle size of soils and were treated as continuous numeric variables for this analysis. Gldrainagecl3 was on a scale from very poorly drained to excessively drained. We reclassified glps1rclss in order to sort the categories on a general scale from fine to coarse. Some soil components lacked data for one or more of these variables, and Minnesota's Cook and Lake Counties also lacked comparable data.
Nutrients were described by nconc and pconc. These variables came from the SPARROW model for the Great Lakes and upper Midwest region that was implemented by the USGS Wisconsin Water Science Center (http://wi.water.usgs.gov/rna/9km30/index.html). We used estimates for nitrogen and phosphorous concentrations that were developed based on the RF1 watersheds.
Road density was described by rddensXcatchmnt. This variable was calculated based on the total linear distance of roads found within NHDPlus Catchments(v1). The road data came from several sources used in GLRI efforts and were provided by Jana Stewart of the USGS Wisconsin Water Science Center (http://wi.water.usgs.gov/).
Population density was described by pop2000_sqmi. This variable came from the 2000 census data included in ESRI software.
Land-cover change was described by prx_lcc9606_1. This variable represented Euclidian distance to increased development intensity from 1996 through 2006. Land cover data came from the CCAP program (http://www.csc.noaa.gov/crs/lca/greatlakes.html). These data were classified by a system similar to that used by the NLCD program, where developed land consists of four categories: high intensity, medium intensity, and low intensity, and developed-open space. We treated the developed-open space category as a very low intensity category in order to determine increases in development intensity.
Ecoregion was described by ecoreg2. Data came from the Level II Omernick ecoregions (http://www.epa.gov/wed/pages/ecoregions/na_eco.htm#Downloads).
Proximity to agriculture was described by prx_ag2006m. This variable represented the Euclidian distance to agriculture land cover in 2006, and came from Coastal Change Analysis Program Regional Land Cover (CCAP) (http://www.csc.noaa.gov/crs/lca/greatlakes.html).
Proximity to urban development was described by prx_all_devel. This was determined by the Euclidian distance to all four developed categories in the CCAP 2006 land cover data (http://www.csc.noaa.gov/crs/lca/greatlakes.html).

gmd:maintenanceNote.gco:CharacterString: provisional/preliminary data subject to change, not for distribution or inclusion in custom 3rd-party map applications.
